Dispersion in two dimensional channels - the Fick-Jacobs approximation revisited

M. Mangeat    T. Guérin    D. S. Dean Laboratoire Ondes et Matière d’Aquitaine (LOMA), CNRS, UMR 5798 / Université de Bordeaux, F-33400 Talence, France
Abstract

We examine the dispersion of Brownian particles in a symmetric two dimensional channel, this classical problem has been widely studied in the literature using the so called Fick-Jacobs’ approximation and its various improvements. Most studies rely on the reduction to an effective one dimensional diffusion equation, here we derive an explicit formula for the diffusion constant which avoids this reduction. Using this formula the effective diffusion constant can be evaluated numerically without resorting to Brownian simulations. In addition, a perturbation theory can be developed in ε=h0/L𝜀subscriptℎ0𝐿\varepsilon=h_{0}/L where h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} is the characteristic channel height and L𝐿L the period. This perturbation theory confirms the results of Kalinay and Percus (Phys. Rev. E 74, 041203 (2006)), based on the reduction, to one dimensional diffusion are exact at least to 𝒪​(ε6)𝒪superscript𝜀6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}). Furthermore, we show how the Kalinay and Percus pseudo-linear approximation can be straightforwardly recovered. The approach proposed here can also be exploited to yield exact results in the limit ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\to\infty, we show that here the diffusion constant remains finite and show how the result can be obtained with a simple physical argument. Moreover, we show that the correction to the effective diffusion constant is of order 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon and remarkably has a some universal characteristics. Numerically we compare the analytic results obtained with exact numerical calculations for a number of interesting channel geometries.

I Introduction

The dispersion properties of complex systems have a wide range of applications including solid state physics, soft matter physics, biology and chemical engineering van2007 ; gar1985 . In many cases the effective transport properties, such as the late time diffusion constant and effective drift are important quantities to study problems as varied as mixing leBorgne2013stretching ; dentz2011mixing ; barros2012flow , sorting bernate2012stochastic , contaminant spreading brusseau1994transport or reaction kinetics in complex systems con2007 . The computation of such effective transport quantities is a longstanding problem in statistical physics and exploits techniques ranging from probability theory kel1962 through to quantum field theory dea2007 .

Transport, notably diffusion, in channel like geometries arises in a number of important physical contexts, ranging from biophysics through to the study of porous media burada2009diffusion ; malgaretti2013entropic ; bressloff2013stochastic ; holcman2013control . Dispersion in periodic systems such as hard squares or disks placed on a lattice can also be mapped onto diffusion in channel like systems dag2012b . Even if the underlying process in such problems is locally standard Brownian motion, the interplay between geometry and diffusion gives rise to rich behavior, for instance the slowing down of diffusive dispersion due to entropic trapping. In many contexts one is only interested in dispersion along the channel and the problem of computing the effective diffusion constant parallel to the channel is one which has been intensively studied. The first results on diffusion in channels are attributed to Jacobs in Ref. jac1967 where the first form of what is known as the Fick-Jacobs’ (FJ) approximation was derived. Subsequent works zwa1991 ; reg2001 ; kal2005 ; kal2006 ; mar2011 ; bra2009 ; ber2011a ; dag2012 involved improvements to the basic FJ approximation for both two dimensional channels and axisymmetric channels in three dimensions. These studies are based on the effective reduction of the problem of diffusion in the channel, to a one dimensional problem where a particle diffuses in an entropically generated potential, simply related to the local channel width or area, but with an effective local diffusion constant. Once this reduction is carried out the effective diffusion constant can be computed using exact results for the diffusion constant of one-dimensional systems lif1961 ; rei2001 ; costantini1999 .

One of the most successful approaches to the problem of diffusion in a channel was proposed by Kalinay and Percus in Refs. kal2005 ; kal2006 . Here they express the effective local diffusion constant as an expansion in powers of a parameter ε𝜀\varepsilon proportional to the ratio of the typical relaxation times in the perpendicular and parallel direction. Later studies dorfman2014assessing checked that such expansions lead to expressions of the global effective diffusivity that are exact at least to order 𝒪​(ε4)𝒪superscript𝜀4\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{4}). From a probabilistic point of view this latter result is somewhat surprising as the effective process parallel to the channel can clearly never be Markovian and described by an effective one dimensional diffusion equation. Mathematically similar problems, where a higher dimensional Markovian stochastic processes is reduced to a lower dimensional one, occur throughout the physics literature, notably when partially-damped Langevin equations (describing the velocity and position of a particle) are reduced to over-damped Langevin equations (describing only the position). A similar problem arises for a particle carrying a dipole in a spatially varying electric field, here the Langevin equations describing the dipole moment and the position can be reduced to a Langevin equation for just the position. In the class of problems mentioned above, a mathematical process of adiabatic elimination, which amounts to a perturbation expansion in the time scale for the relaxation of the quick variable (velocity or dipole moment for instance) divided by that of the slow position variable can be applied. In most cases the effective process remains Markovian only to first order in perturbation theory mig1980 ; ris1996 ; tou2009 . In this paper we neglect hydrodynamic effects, these can become important for fluid filled channels yang2017 when the particle size becomes comparable to the channel size. This is due to the spatial variation of the local diffusion tensor as one approaches the walls channel. Here we restrict our attention to the dispersion of a point-like particle and we can thus ignore these hydrodynamic effects.

In this paper, we analyze in section II the FJ problem starting from an exact formula for the longitudinal diffusion constant. The formula is derived here using a physical argument for channels in any dimension, and agrees with general Kubo type formulas derived for advection diffusion equations in periodic systems gue2015a ; gue2015b and with the macroscopic transport theory developed by Brenner bre1993 . Then, for two-dimensional channels, we present in section III a very compact analysis which allows us to show in section IV that the results of Ref. kal2006 are exact to 𝒪​(ε6)𝒪superscript𝜀6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}), whereas to date they had been checked only up to 𝒪​(ε4)𝒪superscript𝜀4{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{4}) by using Brenner’s theory dorfman2014assessing . Given what we have stated about adiabatic approximations above, it is very interesting that the method of Ref. kal2006 stays correct up to such a high order. We obtain this result within a formalism that uses analytic functions in a complex plane, and we show in section V how the pseudo-linear approximation of Kalinay and Percus can be recovered. This approximation is based on neglecting terms W′′​(x)superscript𝑊′′𝑥W^{\prime\prime}(x) (where W𝑊W is the local channel width) and higher order derivatives. In section VI, we show how the diffusion constant can be computed exactly for a class of two dimensional channels which can be appropriately parameterized in the complex plane, this reproduces in a very rapid manner the classical result of Zwanzig zwa1982 . We also show in section VII how the same formalism can be applied to the limit ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\to\infty, the exact opposite of the cases usually studied in the literature and in which all approaches based on a dimensional reduction fail. In this limit ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\to\infty, we find the asymptotic value of the diffusion constant (which is non-zero) and we also compute the leading order correction, which is 𝒪​(1/ε)𝒪1𝜀{\cal O}(1/\varepsilon), and which has a prefactor that has a remarkably universal character. A short description of this result was given in man2017 , the derivation presented here is slightly different, as we concentrate here on two dimensional channels, and relies more heavily on complex analysis. Finally, in section VIII we show how the formalism based on the Kubo formula for the diffusion constant can be used to numerically study a wide range of channel geometries, thus avoiding the statistical errors and longer times associated with Brownian simulations. We compare some of the standard variants of the FJ approximation with these results for a number of channel geometries, as well as the high order perturbation theory and large ε𝜀\varepsilon results derived here.

II General equations for diffusion in channels

II.1 Model

In this section, we consider diffusion in a portion of space located between two surfaces of equations y=h1​(𝐱)𝑦subscriptℎ1𝐱y=h_{1}({\bf x}) and y=h2​(𝐱)𝑦subscriptℎ2𝐱y=h_{2}({\bf x}). Here 𝐱𝐱{\bf x} represents the coordinates in the hyperplane parallel to the channel, and y𝑦y is the coordinate in the perpendicular direction. We consider the diffusion of a tracer with isotropic diffusion in the channel, with diffusion constant D𝐷D, and subject to a uniform drift velocity parallel to the channel 𝐮||{\bf u}_{||}. The probability density function (pdf) for the tracer thus obeys the advection-diffusion equation

∂p∂t​(𝐱,y;t)=∇⋅[D​∇p​(𝐱,y;t)−𝐮||​p​(𝐱,y;t)].\frac{\partial p}{\partial t}({\bf x},y;t)=\nabla\cdot\left[D\nabla p({\bf x},y;t)-{\bf u}_{||}p({\bf x},y;t)\right]. (1)

with no-flux boundary condition at the interface. We now define the marginal pdf for the coordinate 𝐱𝐱{\bf x} as

p∗​(𝐱;t)=∫h1​(𝐱)h2​(𝐱)𝑑y​p​(𝐱,y;t)superscript𝑝𝐱𝑡superscriptsubscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐱subscriptℎ2𝐱differential-d𝑦𝑝𝐱𝑦𝑡p^{*}({\bf x};t)=\int_{h_{1}({\bf x})}^{h_{2}({\bf x})}dy\ p({\bf x},y;t) (2)

The basis of FJ type approximations is to find an effective diffusion equation for the marginal pdf in the case where it describes a one dimensional process. In what follows, we will (i) derive an exact equation for p∗​(𝐱,t)superscript𝑝𝐱𝑡p^{*}({\bf x},t) to make the hypotheses of the FJ approximation more explicit, and (ii) we will derive an exact equation for the effective diffusivity.

The no-flux boundary condition at each surface is given explicitly as at the surface y=hα​(𝐱)𝑦subscriptℎ𝛼𝐱y=h_{\alpha}({\bf x}) (for α=1, 2𝛼12\alpha=1,\ 2):

Using these results Eq. (5) simplifies remarkably to give

∂p∗∂t​(𝐱;t)=D​∇||2p∗​(𝐱;t)−∇||⋅[𝐮||​p∗​(𝐱;t)]−D​∇||⋅[p​(𝐱,h2​(𝐱);t)​∇||h2​(𝐱)−p​(𝐱,h1​(𝐱);t)​∇||h1​(𝐱)].\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial t}({\bf x};t)=D\nabla_{||}^{2}p^{*}({\bf x};t)-\nabla_{||}\cdot[{\bf u}_{||}p^{*}({\bf x};t)]-D\nabla_{||}\cdot\left[p({\bf x},h_{2}({\bf x});t)\nabla_{||}h_{2}({\bf x})-p({\bf x},h_{1}({\bf x});t)\nabla_{||}h_{1}({\bf x})\right]. (8)

The above equation is exact and is the main result of this section. Even if it is not a closed equation for p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}, we see that the evolution of the marginal pdf p∗superscript𝑝p^{*} involves only the value of the full probability density at the surfaces y=hα​(𝐱)𝑦subscriptℎ𝛼𝐱y=h_{\alpha}({\bf x}), not in the whole channel.

II.3 The basic Fick-Jacobs’ approximation

The basic FJ approximation is obtained by assuming that p​(𝐱,y,t)≃p0​(𝐱,t)similar-to-or-equals𝑝𝐱𝑦𝑡subscript𝑝0𝐱𝑡p({\bf x},y,t)\simeq p_{0}({\bf x},t), i.e. assuming that it is independent of y𝑦y, and thus one is assuming that the pdf equilibrates in the coordinate y𝑦y. This means that

p∗​(𝐱;t)≃∫h1​(𝐱)h2​(𝐱)𝑑y​p0​(𝐱;t)=H​(𝐱)​p0​(𝐱;t),similar-to-or-equalssuperscript𝑝𝐱𝑡superscriptsubscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐱subscriptℎ2𝐱differential-d𝑦subscript𝑝0𝐱𝑡𝐻𝐱subscript𝑝0𝐱𝑡p^{*}({\bf x};t)\simeq\int_{h_{1}({\bf x})}^{h_{2}({\bf x})}dy\ p_{0}({\bf x};t)=H({\bf x})p_{0}({\bf x};t), (9)

where H​(𝐱)=h2​(𝐱)−h1​(𝐱)𝐻𝐱subscriptℎ2𝐱subscriptℎ1𝐱H({\bf x})=h_{2}({\bf x})-h_{1}({\bf x}) is the total channel width at the in-plane coordinate 𝐱𝐱{\bf x}. The basic FJ approximation then gives

p​(𝐱,h1​(𝐱);t)≃p​(𝐱,h2​(𝐱);t)≃p∗​(𝐱;t)H​(𝐱)similar-to-or-equals𝑝𝐱subscriptℎ1𝐱𝑡𝑝𝐱subscriptℎ2𝐱𝑡similar-to-or-equalssuperscript𝑝𝐱𝑡𝐻𝐱p({\bf x},h_{1}({\bf x});t)\simeq p({\bf x},h_{2}({\bf x});t)\simeq\frac{p^{*}({\bf x};t)}{H({\bf x})} (10)

and so the effective diffusion equation for p∗​(𝐱;t)superscript𝑝𝐱𝑡p^{*}({\bf x};t) becomes

∂p∗∂t(𝐱;t)=D∇||2p∗(𝐱;t)−∇||⋅𝐮||p∗(𝐱;t)−D∇||⋅(p∗(𝐱;t)∇||ln[H(𝐱]).\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial t}({\bf x};t)=D\nabla_{||}^{2}p^{*}({\bf x};t)-\nabla_{||}\cdot{\bf u}_{||}p^{*}({\bf x};t)-D\nabla_{||}\cdot\left(p^{*}({\bf x};t)\nabla_{||}\ln[H({\bf x}]\right). (11)

The physical validity of this approximation is argued to hold when the process relaxes in the y𝑦y direction very quickly with respect to its motion in the direction parallel to the channel; it should hold when H​(𝐱)≪Lmuch-less-than𝐻𝐱𝐿H({\bf x})\ll L where L𝐿L is the length scale over which the total channel width varies. An alternative limit where it holds is when one takes the diffusion to be anisotropic, having a (isotropic) diffusion constant D||D_{||} in the plane and a different diffusion constant D⟂subscript𝐷perpendicular-toD_{\perp} in the perpendicular direction. The FJ approximation then holds in the limit ε=D||/D⟂≪1\varepsilon=D_{||}/D_{\perp}\ll 1, and the problem can be analyzed perturbatively using ε𝜀\varepsilon as the small parameter. Of course the approximation that p​(𝐱,y;t)𝑝𝐱𝑦𝑡p({\bf x},y;t) is independent of y𝑦y clearly does not satisfy the no flux boundary condition in Eq. (4) when ∇||hα≠𝟎\nabla_{||}h_{\alpha}\neq{\bf 0}. An important success of the FJ approximation is that it gives the correct equilibrium distribution in the steady state. On a unit cell ΩΩ\Omega of the channel (which is repeated to form the infinite channel) the equilibrium distribution is clearly uniform within the channel and thus the marginal pdf for the in plane coordinate 𝐱𝐱{\bf x} is

Ps​(𝐱)=H​(𝐱)∫Ω𝑑𝐱′​H​(𝐱′).subscript𝑃𝑠𝐱𝐻𝐱subscriptΩdifferential-dsuperscript𝐱′𝐻superscript𝐱′P_{s}({\bf x})=\frac{H({\bf x})}{\int_{\Omega}d{\bf x^{\prime}}H({\bf x^{\prime}})}. (12)

This means that the 𝐱𝐱{\bf x} in-plane coordinate of the tracer particle is subjected to an effective entropic potential

ϕent​(𝐱)=−kB​T​ln⁡(H​(𝐱)).subscriptitalic-ϕent𝐱subscript𝑘𝐵𝑇𝐻𝐱\phi_{\rm ent}({\bf x})=-k_{B}T\ln(H({\bf x})). (13)

For effectively two dimensional systems (that is to say two dimensional channels or three dimensional ones with rotational symmetry) a number of authors have suggested improvements to the Fick-Jacobs approximation in the form an effective in plane diffusion constant D​(x)𝐷𝑥D(x) which depends on the local height functions (in general both h2subscriptℎ2h_{2} and h1subscriptℎ1h_{1} and not just their difference). Clearly if an underlying one dimensional diffusion equation were to exist it would have to have the steady state distribution given by Eq. (12) and thus have the general form, in the absence of external drift,

∂p∗∂t​(x;t)=∂∂x​D​(x)​[∂p∗∂x​(x;t)+β​∂ϕent∂x​(x)​p∗​(x;t)],superscript𝑝𝑡𝑥𝑡𝑥𝐷𝑥delimited-[]superscript𝑝𝑥𝑥𝑡𝛽subscriptitalic-ϕent𝑥𝑥superscript𝑝𝑥𝑡\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial t}(x;t)=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}D(x)\left[\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial x}(x;t)+\beta\frac{\partial\phi_{\rm ent}}{\partial x}(x)p^{*}(x;t)\right], (14)

with β=1/kB​T𝛽1subscript𝑘𝐵𝑇\beta=1/k_{B}T. The effective diffusion constant for the effective one dimensional problem can then be extracted using the exact formula for one dimensional diffusion lif1961

De=1⟨D−1​(x)​exp⁡(β​ϕent​(x))⟩s​⟨exp⁡(−β​ϕent​(x))⟩s,subscript𝐷𝑒1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝐷1𝑥𝛽subscriptitalic-ϕent𝑥𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝛽subscriptitalic-ϕent𝑥𝑠D_{e}=\frac{1}{\langle D^{-1}(x)\exp\left(\beta\phi_{\rm ent}(x)\right)\rangle_{s}\langle\exp\left(-\beta\phi_{\rm ent}(x)\right)\rangle_{s}}, (15)

where the angled bracket indicate the spatial average over one period of the system, i.e.

⟨f⟩s=1L​∫0L𝑑x​f​(x).subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑓𝑠1𝐿superscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥𝑓𝑥\langle f\rangle_{s}=\frac{1}{L}\int_{0}^{L}dx\ f(x). (16)

These approaches all agree in an expansion based on ε=D⟂/D||\varepsilon=D_{\perp}/D_{||} being small but differ at higher orders. However, as mentioned in the introduction, this approach clearly cannot be valid exactly as the process projected onto the in-plane coordinates is evidently not Markovian and thus cannot be described by a diffusion equation with local transport coefficients. As mentioned in the introduction, a similar phenomenon appears in the theory of stochastic processes where a fast variable is eliminated from a stochastic differential equation using an adiabatic approximation scheme mig1980 ; ris1996 ; tou2009 . It is generally found that the process remains Markovian at the first order of correction but does not remain so when higher order corrections are included.

II.4 General formula for the diffusion constant

In this paper we will use an exact formula for the diffusion constant, of the process in the plane of the channel, which does not use a reduction of the problem to a lower dimensional one. The formulas for the diffusion constant can be directly written down using a general theory for diffusion in periodic systems developed in gue2015a ; gue2015b . These formulas are formally exact – however, they require the solution of partial differential equations which are not analytically soluble in two dimensions and higher. Nevertheless, the relevant equations can be treated using approximation methods for narrow channel geometries which are similar to those which are employed to derive improvements to the FJ approximation and which are used as the basis for lubrication theory in fluid dynamics lub .

From now on, we consider that h1subscriptℎ1h_{1} and h2subscriptℎ2h_{2} are spatially periodic, and of the same periodicity. Rather than simply quoting the results of gue2015a ; gue2015b , we provide a quick re derivation of the result, ideally suited to the channel geometry and based on simple physical arguments. To begin with we compete the average drift of a tracer in the in plane coordinates,

d​⟨Xi⟩d​t=∫𝑑𝐱​𝑑y​xi​∂p∂t​(𝐱,y;t)=∫𝑑𝐱​xi​∂p∗∂t​(𝐱,t),𝑑delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑋𝑖𝑑𝑡differential-d𝐱differential-d𝑦subscript𝑥𝑖𝑝𝑡𝐱𝑦𝑡differential-d𝐱subscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝑝𝑡𝐱𝑡\frac{d\langle X_{i}\rangle}{dt}=\int d{\bf x}dy\ x_{i}\frac{\partial p}{\partial t}({\bf x},y;t)=\int d{\bf x}\ x_{i}\frac{\partial p^{*}}{\partial t}({\bf x},t), (17)

and we now use Eq. (8) and integration by parts to give an effective drift

d​⟨𝐗⟩d​t=𝐮||+D​∫𝑑𝐱​[p​(𝐱,h2​(𝐱);t)​∇||h2​(𝐱)−p​(𝐱,h1​(𝐱);t)​∇||h1​(𝐱)].\frac{d\langle{\bf X}\rangle}{dt}={\bf u}_{||}+D\int d{\bf x}\left[p\left({\bf x},h_{2}({\bf x});t\right)\nabla_{||}h_{2}({\bf x})-p\left({\bf x},h_{1}({\bf x});t\right)\nabla_{||}h_{1}({\bf x})\right]. (18)

In the steady state we can replace p​(𝐱,h2​(𝐱);t)𝑝𝐱subscriptℎ2𝐱𝑡p\left({\bf x},h_{2}({\bf x});t\right) by their steady state values on the unit cell ΩΩ\Omega, denoted by Ps​(𝐱,y)subscript𝑃𝑠𝐱𝑦P_{s}({\bf x},y) and use periodicity to restrict the 𝐱𝐱{\bf x} integral over the in-plane coordinates of ΩΩ\Omega denoted by Ω||\Omega_{||}, to find

d​⟨𝐗⟩d​t=𝐮||+D​∫Ω||𝑑𝐱​[Ps​(𝐱,h2​(𝐱))​∇||h2​(𝐱)−Ps​(𝐱,h1​(𝐱))​∇||h1​(𝐱)].\frac{d\langle{\bf X}\rangle}{dt}={\bf u}_{||}+D\int_{\Omega_{||}}d{\bf x}\left[P_{s}\left({\bf x},h_{2}({\bf x})\right)\nabla_{||}h_{2}({\bf x})-P_{s}\left({\bf x},h_{1}({\bf x})\right)\nabla_{||}h_{1}({\bf x})\right]. (19)

Now we suppose that the drift 𝐮||{\bf u}_{||} is induced by an infinitesimal applied force 𝐅||{\bf F}_{||}, i.e. 𝐮||=D​β​𝐅||{\bf u}_{||}=D\beta{\bf F}_{||}. This local constant applied force will give rise to an effective late time, or asymptotic, drift which is defined by V||i=d​⟨Xi⟩/d​tV_{||i}=d\langle X_{i}\rangle/dt. The Stokes Einstein relation then gives

V||i=β​Dei​j​F||j=Dei​jD​u||j,V_{||i}=\beta D_{e}^{ij}{F}_{||j}=\frac{D_{e}^{ij}}{D}{u}_{||j}, (20)

where the Einstein convention on index summation is used, and Dei​jsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑒𝑖𝑗D_{e}^{ij} is the effective diffusion tensor in the in-plane coordinates, given for 𝐮||=0{\bf u}_{||}=0 by

Dei​j=limt→∞⟨xi​(t)​xj​(t)⟩2​tsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑒𝑖𝑗subscript→𝑡delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑗𝑡2𝑡\displaystyle D_{e}^{ij}=\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\frac{\langle x_{i}(t)x_{j}(t)\rangle}{2t} (21)

The steady state distribution obeys

∇⋅[D​∇Ps​(𝐱,y)−𝐮||​Ps​(𝐱,y)]=0,\nabla\cdot\left[D\nabla P_{s}({\bf x},y)-{\bf u}_{||}P_{s}({\bf x},y)\right]=0, (22)

and then assuming that u⟂=0subscript𝑢perpendicular-to0u_{\perp}=0 and 𝐮||{\bf u}_{||} is small we can write

Ps​(𝐱,y)=1Ω+u||j​∂Ps∂u||j​(𝐱,y),P_{s}({\bf x},y)=\frac{1}{\Omega}+u_{||j}\frac{\partial P_{s}}{\partial u_{||j}}({\bf x},y), (23)

where we have also used ΩΩ\Omega to denote the volume of the unit cell ΩΩ\Omega. We write fi=D​∂Ps∂u||if_{i}=D\frac{\partial P_{s}}{\partial u_{||i}} and so the Stokes Einstein formula gives

Dei​jD=δi​j+∫Ω||𝑑𝐱​[fj​(𝐱,h2​(𝐱))​∇||ih2​(𝐱)−fj​(𝐱,h1​(𝐱))​∇||ih1​(𝐱)].\frac{D_{e}^{ij}}{D}=\delta_{ij}+\int_{\Omega_{||}}d{\bf x}\left[f_{j}\left({\bf x},h_{2}({\bf x})\right)\nabla_{||i}h_{2}({\bf x})-f_{j}\left({\bf x},h_{1}({\bf x})\right)\nabla_{||i}h_{1}({\bf x})\right]. (24)

Differentiating the steady state equation (22) with respect to u||iu_{||i} and then setting u||i=0u_{||i}=0 yields the equation obeyed by the vector field fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}:

∇2fi=0.superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖0\nabla^{2}f_{i}=0. (25)

Furthermore, fi​(𝐱,y)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝑦f_{i}({\bf x},y) must be periodic in the in plane coordinates 𝐱𝐱{\bf x} and the normalization of the steady state distribution over ΩΩ\Omega implies that

∫Ω𝑑y​𝑑𝐱​fi​(𝐱,y)=0,subscriptΩdifferential-d𝑦differential-d𝐱subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝑦0\int_{\Omega}dyd{\bf x}\ f_{i}({\bf x},y)=0, (26)

while the no flux boundary conditions at the channel surface imposes

𝐧α⋅[−∇fi​(𝐱,y)|y=hα​(𝐱)+𝐞iΩ]=0,⋅subscript𝐧𝛼delimited-[]evaluated-at∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝑦𝑦subscriptℎ𝛼𝐱subscript𝐞𝑖Ω0{\bf n_{\alpha}}\cdot\left[-\nabla f_{i}\left({\bf x},y\right)|_{y=h_{\alpha}({\bf x})}+\frac{{\bf e}_{i}}{\Omega}\right]=0, (27)

where 𝐞isubscript𝐞𝑖{\bf e}_{i} denotes the unit vector in the direction i𝑖i in the plane parallel to the channel. The above condition can be rewritten as

−∇||hα​(𝐱)⋅∇||fi​(𝐱,y)|y=hα​(𝐱)+∂fi∂y​(𝐱,hα​(𝐱))=−∇||ihα​(𝐱)Ω.-\nabla_{||}h_{\alpha}({\bf x})\cdot\nabla_{||}f_{i}\left({\bf x},y\right)|_{y=h_{\alpha}({\bf x})}+\frac{\partial f_{i}}{\partial y}({\bf x},h_{\alpha}({\bf x}))=-\frac{\nabla_{||i}h_{\alpha}({\bf x})}{\Omega}. (28)

To summarize, an exact formula for the effective diffusivity is given by Eq. (24), where the auxiliary function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is computed by solving Laplace’s equation (25) with boundary conditions (28). The above results are in full accordance with the general theory of Refs. gue2015a ; gue2015b and with the Brenner macro transport theory bre1993 .

III Formulation of the problem with analytic functions for two dimensional symmetric channels

Most studies in the literature have considered the case where the channel is two dimensional. Here we will denote the coordinate along the channel as x𝑥x and, as earlier, use y𝑦y to denote the height coordinate. We will consider channels which are symmetric about the axis y=0𝑦0y=0, that is to say we write h​(x)=h2​(x)=−h1​(x)ℎ𝑥subscriptℎ2𝑥subscriptℎ1𝑥h(x)=h_{2}(x)=-h_{1}(x). We define L𝐿L as the period of the channel, so that h​(x+L)=h​(x)ℎ𝑥𝐿ℎ𝑥h(x+L)=h(x).

Here there is only one variable f1=fsubscript𝑓1𝑓f_{1}=f corresponding to the x𝑥x direction it obeys Laplace’s equation

∇2f​(x,y)=0.superscript∇2𝑓𝑥𝑦0\nabla^{2}f(x,y)=0. (29)

The solution of Laplace’s equation can be written using the theory of analytic functions as the real or imaginary part (or a linear combination of both) of

f​(x,y)=W1​(z)+W2​(z¯),𝑓𝑥𝑦subscript𝑊1𝑧subscript𝑊2¯𝑧f(x,y)=W_{1}(z)+W_{2}(\overline{z}), (30)

where z=x+i​y𝑧𝑥𝑖𝑦z=x+iy and z¯=x−i​y¯𝑧𝑥𝑖𝑦\overline{z}=x-iy denotes its complex conjugate. For symmetric channels, the symmetry about y=0𝑦0y=0 implies that f​(x,y)=f​(x,−y)𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑓𝑥𝑦f(x,y)=f(x,-y) and thus one can easily see that

W1​(z)=W2​(z)+c,subscript𝑊1𝑧subscript𝑊2𝑧𝑐W_{1}(z)=W_{2}(z)+c, (31)

where c𝑐c is a constant. However, c𝑐c can simply be incorporated into the definition of W1subscript𝑊1W_{1} so we can use the form

f​(x,y)=W1​(z)+W1​(z¯).𝑓𝑥𝑦subscript𝑊1𝑧subscript𝑊1¯𝑧f(x,y)=W_{1}(z)+W_{1}(\overline{z}). (32)

Since f​(x,y)𝑓𝑥𝑦f(x,y) is real, we can assume without loss of generality that the coefficients of the Laurent expansion of W1subscript𝑊1W_{1} are real, so that W1​(z)¯=W1​(z¯)¯subscript𝑊1𝑧subscript𝑊1¯𝑧\overline{W_{1}(z)}=W_{1}(\overline{z}). Making a convenient rescaling in terms of the unit channel area ΩΩ\Omega we thus see that, for a symmetric channel, one can look for solutions of the form

f​(x,y)=12​Ω​[w​(x+i​y)+w​(x−i​y)],𝑓𝑥𝑦12Ωdelimited-[]𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦f(x,y)=\frac{1}{2\Omega}[w(x+iy)+w(x-iy)], (33)

where w𝑤w is analytic such that w​(z)¯=w​(z¯)¯𝑤𝑧𝑤¯𝑧\overline{w(z)}=w(\overline{z}) and is periodic in x𝑥x (with period L𝐿L). If we write w𝑤w in terms of its real and imaginary parts, w​(x+i​y)=u​(x,y)+i​v​(x,y)𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑖𝑣𝑥𝑦w(x+iy)=u(x,y)+iv(x,y), the symmetry y→−y→𝑦𝑦y\to-y implies that

u​(x,−y)=u​(x,y)𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑢𝑥𝑦u(x,-y)=u(x,y) (34)

This means, looking at an expansion in terms of y𝑦y at fixed x𝑥x, that ∂u/∂y𝑢𝑦\partial u/\partial y is an odd function in y𝑦y. However, the Cauchy-Riemann equation

∂u∂y​(x,y)=−∂v∂x​(x,y),𝑢𝑦𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑥𝑦\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}(x,y)=-\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}(x,y), (35)

shows that ∂v/∂x𝑣𝑥\partial v/\partial x is odd in y𝑦y. However, at y=0𝑦0y=0 this equation implies, as ∂u∂y|y=0=0evaluated-at𝑢𝑦𝑦00\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}|_{y=0}=0, that v​(x,0)𝑣𝑥0v(x,0) is a constant (v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}). Consequently, we have, integrating Eq. (35) over x𝑥x, that

v​(x,y)=v0+V​(x,y)𝑣𝑥𝑦subscript𝑣0𝑉𝑥𝑦v(x,y)=v_{0}+V(x,y) (36)

where V​(x,−y)=−V​(x,y)𝑉𝑥𝑦𝑉𝑥𝑦V(x,-y)=-V(x,y). However there is nothing in the problem that allows the determination of v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}, furthermore one can show that it does not affect the value of the diffusion constant, and we thus chose v0=0subscript𝑣00v_{0}=0 and so v​(x,−y)=−v​(x,y)𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦v(x,-y)=-v(x,y).

Inserting the ansatz in Eq. (33) into the boundary condition (28) provides an additional condition for the value of w𝑤w at the channel boundary:

i​h′​(x)​[w′​(x+i​h​(x))+w′​(x−i​h​(x))]+[w′​(x+i​h​(x))−w′​(x−i​h​(x))]=i​2​h′​(x),𝑖superscriptℎ′𝑥delimited-[]superscript𝑤′𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥superscript𝑤′𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥delimited-[]superscript𝑤′𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥superscript𝑤′𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥𝑖2superscriptℎ′𝑥ih^{\prime}(x)[w^{\prime}\left(x+ih(x))+w^{\prime}(x-ih(x)\right)]+[w^{\prime}\left(x+ih(x)\right)-w^{\prime}\left(x-ih(x)\right)]=i2{h^{\prime}(x)}, (37)

and this can be integrated with respect to x𝑥x to yield

w​(x+i​h​(x))−w​(x−i​h​(x))=2​i​h​(x)−i​2​C,𝑤𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥𝑤𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥2𝑖ℎ𝑥𝑖2𝐶w\left(x+ih(x)\right)-w\left(x-ih(x)\right)=2ih(x)-i2C, (38)

where C𝐶C is a constant to be determined. Finally, the effective diffusivity is given by

DeD=1+2​∫0L𝑑x​f​(x,h​(x))​h′​(x),subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷12superscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥𝑓𝑥ℎ𝑥superscriptℎ′𝑥\frac{D_{e}}{D}=1+2\int_{0}^{L}d{x}f({x},h({x}))h^{\prime}({x}), (39)

and so within this formalism, the diffusion constant is simply given by

DeDsubscript𝐷𝑒𝐷\displaystyle\frac{D_{e}}{D} =\displaystyle= 1+1Ω​∫0L𝑑x​[w​(x+i​h​(x))+w​(x−i​h​(x))]​h′​(x).11Ωsuperscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥delimited-[]𝑤𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥𝑤𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥superscriptℎ′𝑥\displaystyle 1+\frac{1}{\Omega}\int_{0}^{L}d{x}[w\left(x+ih(x)\right)+w\left(x-ih(x)\right)]h^{\prime}({x}). (40)

However, we show in appendix A that the above equation can be simplified, leading to

DeDsubscript𝐷𝑒𝐷\displaystyle\frac{D_{e}}{D} =\displaystyle= C⟨h⟩s,,𝐶subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠\displaystyle\frac{C}{\langle h\rangle_{s}},, (41)

where

⟨h⟩s=1L​∫0L𝑑x​h​(x),subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠1𝐿superscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥ℎ𝑥{\langle h\rangle_{s}}=\frac{1}{L}\int_{0}^{L}dx\ h(x), (42)

is the channel height spatially averaged over one period. In the following section we present an alternative proof based on a perturbation expansion.

We have thus reformulated the diffusivity problem for two-dimensional symmetric channels into a problem of finding an analytic function w​(z)𝑤𝑧w(z) in the complex plane z=x+i​y𝑧𝑥𝑖𝑦z=x+iy, with the condition (38) at the channel boundary. Remarkably, once the constant C𝐶C is determined in (38), there is no more integration to be done to determine Desubscript𝐷𝑒D_{e} which is directly proportional to this constant [ see Eq. (41)]. The use of analytic functions to analyze FJ type problems in two dimensional channels has of course been exploited in a number of studies kal2010 ; kal2014 ; kal2015 ; however, the present study shows that this method can be exploited much further.

IV Perturbation expansion for the effective diffusivity

IV.1 Recovering the basic Fick-Jacobs’ approximation

We now show how our complex formalism can be used to recover the basic FJ approximation for the effective diffusivity. To proceed we assume that the length of the channel is much larger than the height and thus expand Eq. (38) for small hℎh which gives

w′​(x)​h​(x)=h​(x)−C,superscript𝑤′𝑥ℎ𝑥ℎ𝑥𝐶w^{\prime}(x)h(x)=h(x)-C, (43)

Integrating and using the periodicity of w𝑤w we find

w​(x)=[x−⟨h−1⟩s−1​∫0xd​x′h​(x′)]+C′𝑤𝑥delimited-[]𝑥subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptℎ11𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝑥𝑑superscript𝑥′ℎsuperscript𝑥′superscript𝐶′w(x)=\left[x-\langle h^{-1}\rangle^{-1}_{s}\int_{0}^{x}\frac{dx^{\prime}}{h(x^{\prime})}\right]+C^{\prime} (44)

where

⟨h−1⟩s=1L​∫0Ld​x′h​(x′),subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptℎ1𝑠1𝐿superscriptsubscript0𝐿𝑑superscript𝑥′ℎsuperscript𝑥′\langle h^{-1}\rangle_{s}=\frac{1}{L}\int_{0}^{L}\frac{dx^{\prime}}{h(x^{\prime})}, (45)

is the spatial average of h−1superscriptℎ1h^{-1} over the unit cell. The term C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} is determined from the normalization condition but we do not need to evaluate it gives zero contribution to the effective diffusivity as can be easily seen in Eq. (40). Keeping the leading order in hℎh in Eq. (40) now gives

DeD≃1−2Ω​∫0L𝑑x​w′​(x)​h​(x).similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝐷𝑒𝐷12Ωsuperscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥superscript𝑤′𝑥ℎ𝑥\frac{D_{e}}{D}\simeq 1-\frac{2}{\Omega}\int_{0}^{L}d{x}\ w^{\prime}({x})h(x). (46)

Now, noting that Ω=2​∫0L𝑑x​h​(x)Ω2superscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥ℎ𝑥\Omega=2\int_{0}^{L}dx\ h(x) we find

DeD≈DFJD=1⟨h−1⟩s​⟨h⟩s,subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷subscript𝐷FJ𝐷1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptℎ1𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠\frac{D_{e}}{D}\approx\frac{D_{\rm FJ}}{D}=\frac{1}{\langle h^{-1}\rangle_{s}\langle h\rangle_{s}}, (47)

this is exactly the same result as given by the basic FJ formula (that is to say with no modifications to the local diffusion constant).

IV.2 Perturbation theory in channel width

We now consider a channel height of the form

h​(x)=ε​ζ​(x),ℎ𝑥𝜀𝜁𝑥\displaystyle h(x)=\varepsilon\zeta(x), (48)

which we will analyze here in the limit of small ε𝜀\varepsilon. We now show that our complex formalism can be systematically improved to obtain an expansion of the effective diffusivity in powers of the small parameter ε𝜀\varepsilon in a very compact way.

The whole perturbation analysis for the function w​(x)𝑤𝑥w(x) is based on Eq. (38) which can be written as

∑n=0∞(−1)n​ε2​n+1​w(2​n+1)​(x)​ζ2​n+1​(x)(2​n+1)!=ε​ζ​(x)−C,superscriptsubscript𝑛0superscript1𝑛superscript𝜀2𝑛1superscript𝑤2𝑛1𝑥superscript𝜁2𝑛1𝑥2𝑛1𝜀𝜁𝑥𝐶\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n}\varepsilon^{2n+1}\frac{w^{(2n+1)}(x)\zeta^{2n+1}(x)}{(2n+1)!}={\varepsilon\zeta(x)-C}, (49)

where we use the notation w(n)=dn​w/d​xnsuperscript𝑤𝑛superscript𝑑𝑛𝑤𝑑superscript𝑥𝑛w^{(n)}=d^{n}w/dx^{n}. The above equation is compatible with an expansion of w𝑤w in even powers of ε𝜀\varepsilon of the form

w​(x)=∑m=0∞ε2​m​w2​m​(x),𝑤𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑚0superscript𝜀2𝑚subscript𝑤2𝑚𝑥w(x)=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\varepsilon^{2m}w_{2m}(x), (50)

and the constant C𝐶C of the form

C=ε​∑k=0∞ε2​k​C2​k.𝐶𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑘0superscript𝜀2𝑘subscript𝐶2𝑘C=\varepsilon\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\varepsilon^{2k}C_{2k}. (51)

The boundary condition Eq. (38), expressed as a perturbation series in ε𝜀\varepsilon, now becomes for k>0𝑘0k>0,

∑n,m=0∞(−1)n​ε2​n+2​m​w2​m(2​n+1)​(x)​ζ2​n+1​(x)(2​n+1)!=ζ​(x)−∑k=0∞ε2​k​C2​k.superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚0superscript1𝑛superscript𝜀2𝑛2𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑤2𝑚2𝑛1𝑥superscript𝜁2𝑛1𝑥2𝑛1𝜁𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘0superscript𝜀2𝑘subscript𝐶2𝑘\sum_{n,m=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n}\varepsilon^{2n+2m}\frac{w_{2m}^{(2n+1)}(x)\zeta^{2n+1}(x)}{(2n+1)!}={\zeta(x)-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\varepsilon^{2k}C_{2k}}. (52)

We can compute directly using Eq. (39), the expansion in ε𝜀\varepsilon of the effective diffusivity, finding

DeD=1−1⟨ζ⟩s​∫0L𝑑x​∑n=0∞(−1)n​ε2​n​w(2​n+1)​(x)​ζ2​n+1​(x)(2​n+1)!,subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷11subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑛0superscript1𝑛superscript𝜀2𝑛superscript𝑤2𝑛1𝑥superscript𝜁2𝑛1𝑥2𝑛1\frac{D_{e}}{D}=1-\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}\int_{0}^{L}d{x}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n}\varepsilon^{2n}\frac{w^{(2n+1)}(x)\zeta^{2n+1}(x)}{(2n+1)!}, (53)

after an integration by parts. It follows from the relation Eq. (49) that the constants Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} directly provide the terms of the perturbative expansion of the effective diffusion constant, which reads

DeD=Cε​⟨ζ⟩s=1⟨ζ⟩s​∑k=0∞C2​k​ε2​k,subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷𝐶𝜀subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝐶2𝑘superscript𝜀2𝑘\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{C}{\varepsilon\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}=\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}C_{2k}\varepsilon^{2k}, (54)

thus providing an alternative derivation of Eq. (41) to that derived in appendix A.

This agrees with the results of Refs. kal2006 ; dorfman2014assessing . In Ref. kal2006 the result was obtained by a formalism which derives an effective one dimensional diffusion constant. However, as pointed out before, the reduction to an effective one dimensional problem is not obvious as the resulting one dimensional process is non-Markovian. In Ref. dorfman2014assessing the effective macroscopic transport theory of Brenner bre1993 was used. The expression for the diffusion constant in this theory can actually be shown to agree with the Kubo formula derived here. An interesting point made in Ref. dorfman2014assessing is that the result of Ref. kal2006 is recovered at orders up to and including ε4superscript𝜀4\varepsilon^{4}.

Here we exploit the compact nature of the analysis here to derive the term of 𝒪​(ε6)𝒪superscript𝜀6\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^{6}) and show that it still agrees with Ref. kal2006 . V The pseudo-linear channel approximation

In Ref. kal2006 the perturbation theory was partially resumed by assuming that derivatives ζ′′superscript𝜁′′\zeta^{\prime\prime} and of higher order vanish. Here we show how this re summation can be derived within the formalism developed here in a very compact manner. We start from the Eq. (38) and make the ansatz

w​(x+i​y)=x+i​y−1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫0x+i​y𝑑ξ​ϕ​(ξ),𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑥𝑖𝑦1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝑥𝑖𝑦differential-d𝜉italic-ϕ𝜉w(x+iy)=x+iy-\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int_{0}^{x+iy}d\xi\phi(\xi), (72)

where

⟨ϕ⟩s=∫01ϕ​(x)​𝑑xsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript01italic-ϕ𝑥differential-d𝑥\langle\phi\rangle_{s}=\int_{0}^{1}\phi(x)dx (73)

is the integral of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi along the line y=0𝑦0y=0. In addition, we assume that ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is analytic and so the integral in the second term on the right hand side is independent of the integration path between 00 and x+i​y𝑥𝑖𝑦x+iy. We also assume that ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is of period 111 in the variable x𝑥x, i.e. ϕ​(x+1+i​y)=ϕ​(x+i​y)italic-ϕ𝑥1𝑖𝑦italic-ϕ𝑥𝑖𝑦\phi(x+1+iy)=\phi(x+iy), so we are working in units where the period L=1𝐿1L=1 to simplify notation.

We now note that the function w𝑤w so constructed is analytic and is periodic in x𝑥x with period 111. To see this latter point we write

w​(x+1+i​y)=x+1+i​y−1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫0x+1+i​y𝑑ξ​ϕ​(ξ).𝑤𝑥1𝑖𝑦𝑥1𝑖𝑦1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝑥1𝑖𝑦differential-d𝜉italic-ϕ𝜉w(x+1+iy)=x+1+iy-\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int_{0}^{x+1+iy}d\xi\phi(\xi). (74)

The contour integral on the right hand side can be decomposed into an integral along the real axis between 00 and x+1𝑥1x+1 followed by an integral parallel to the imaginary axis between x+1𝑥1x+1 and x+1+i​y𝑥1𝑖𝑦x+1+iy so we can write

w​(x+1+i​y)=x+1+i​y−1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫0x+1𝑑x′​ϕ​(x′)−i⟨ϕ⟩s​∫0y𝑑y′​ϕ​(x+1+i​y′)𝑤𝑥1𝑖𝑦𝑥1𝑖𝑦1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝑥1differential-dsuperscript𝑥′italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥′𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝑦differential-dsuperscript𝑦′italic-ϕ𝑥1𝑖superscript𝑦′w(x+1+iy)=x+1+iy-\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int_{0}^{x+1}dx^{\prime}\phi(x^{\prime})-\frac{i}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int_{0}^{y}dy^{\prime}\phi(x+1+iy^{\prime}) (75)

However, by the periodicity of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi we can write

1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫0x+1𝑑x′​ϕ​(x′)=1+1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫0x𝑑x′​ϕ​(x′)1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝑥1differential-dsuperscript𝑥′italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥′11subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript0𝑥differential-dsuperscript𝑥′italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥′\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int_{0}^{x+1}dx^{\prime}\phi(x^{\prime})=1+\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int_{0}^{x}dx^{\prime}\phi(x^{\prime}) (76)

and

∫0y𝑑y′​ϕ​(x+1+i​y′)=∫0y𝑑y′​ϕ​(x+i​y′),superscriptsubscript0𝑦differential-dsuperscript𝑦′italic-ϕ𝑥1𝑖superscript𝑦′superscriptsubscript0𝑦differential-dsuperscript𝑦′italic-ϕ𝑥𝑖superscript𝑦′\int_{0}^{y}dy^{\prime}\phi(x+1+iy^{\prime})=\int_{0}^{y}dy^{\prime}\phi(x+iy^{\prime}), (77)

which once inserted into (74) proves the desired periodicity, i.e. w​(x+1+i​y)=w​(x+i​y)𝑤𝑥1𝑖𝑦𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦w(x+1+iy)=w(x+iy). We now substitute this ansatz into the boundary condition (38) which becomes

1⟨ϕ⟩s​[∫0x+i​h​(x)𝑑ξ​ϕ​(ξ)−∫0x−i​h​(x)𝑑ξ​ϕ​(ξ)]=2​i​C1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠delimited-[]superscriptsubscript0𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥differential-d𝜉italic-ϕ𝜉superscriptsubscript0𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥differential-d𝜉italic-ϕ𝜉2𝑖𝐶\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\left[\int_{0}^{x+ih(x)}d\xi\phi(\xi)-\int_{0}^{x-ih(x)}d\xi\phi(\xi)\right]=2iC (78)

We now note that the overall contour integral on the left hand side goes over the line between x−i​h​(x)𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥x-ih(x) and 00 then the line from 00 to x+i​h​(x)𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥x+ih(x). Using the analytic property of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi we deform the contour to the straight line between x−i​h​(x)𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥x-ih(x) and x+i​h​(x)𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥x+ih(x) which is parallel to the imaginary axis so we can write

1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫−11𝑑s​h​(x)​ϕ​(x+i​s​h​(x))=2​C.1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠superscriptsubscript11differential-d𝑠ℎ𝑥italic-ϕ𝑥𝑖𝑠ℎ𝑥2𝐶\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int_{-1}^{1}ds\ h(x)\ \phi\left(x+ish(x)\right)=2C. (79)

It is easy to verify that if we write h​(x)=ε​ζ​(x)ℎ𝑥𝜀𝜁𝑥h(x)=\varepsilon\zeta(x) the above generates the same perturbation theory as was found in the previous section. However, the starting point of the perturbation theory can be changed by writing

ϕ​(ξ)=ψ​(ξ)h​(ξ),italic-ϕ𝜉𝜓𝜉ℎ𝜉\phi(\xi)=\frac{\psi(\xi)}{h(\xi)}, (80)

which leads to

1⟨ψh⟩s​∫−11𝑑s​ζ​(x)​ψ​(x+i​s​ε​ζ​(x))ζ​(x+i​s​ε​ζ​(x))=2​C.1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜓ℎ𝑠superscriptsubscript11differential-d𝑠𝜁𝑥𝜓𝑥𝑖𝑠𝜀𝜁𝑥𝜁𝑥𝑖𝑠𝜀𝜁𝑥2𝐶\frac{1}{\langle\frac{\psi}{h}\rangle_{s}}\int_{-1}^{1}ds\ \zeta(x)\ \frac{\psi\left(x+is\varepsilon\zeta(x)\right)}{\zeta\left(x+is\varepsilon\zeta(x)\right)}=2C. (81)

At lowest order in ε𝜀\varepsilon it is easy to verify using Eq. (54) that this recovers the basic FJ approximation as the solution is ψ​(x)=ψ0𝜓𝑥subscript𝜓0\psi(x)=\psi_{0} where ψ0subscript𝜓0\psi_{0} is constant.

To recover the pseudo-linear approximation of kal2006 , we proceed as follows. First, we ignore the terms ζ′′​(x)superscript𝜁′′𝑥\zeta^{\prime\prime}(x) and higher orders in Taylor expanding the denominator of the integrand on the right hand side of Eq. (81), so that we approximate

ζ​(x+i​s​ε​ζ​(x))≃ζ​(x)+ζ′​(x)​i​s​ε​ζ​(x)similar-to-or-equals𝜁𝑥𝑖𝑠𝜀𝜁𝑥𝜁𝑥superscript𝜁′𝑥𝑖𝑠𝜀𝜁𝑥\displaystyle\zeta(x+is\varepsilon\zeta(x))\simeq\zeta(x)+\zeta^{\prime}(x)\ is\varepsilon\zeta(x) (82)

Next, we also write

ψ​(x+i​s​ε​ζ​(x))≈ψ​(x),𝜓𝑥𝑖𝑠𝜀𝜁𝑥𝜓𝑥\displaystyle\psi\left(x+is\varepsilon\zeta(x)\right)\approx\psi(x), (83)

later we will verify that this is consistent with neglecting terms h′′superscriptℎ′′h^{\prime\prime} and higher derivatives. With these approximations, Eq. (81) becomes

ψ​(x)⟨ψh⟩s​∫−11d​s1+i​s​ε​ζ′​(x)=2​C.𝜓𝑥subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜓ℎ𝑠superscriptsubscript11𝑑𝑠1𝑖𝑠𝜀superscript𝜁′𝑥2𝐶\frac{\psi(x)}{\langle\frac{\psi}{h}\rangle_{s}}\int_{-1}^{1}\frac{ds}{1+is\varepsilon\zeta^{\prime}(x)}=2C. (84)

Performing the integral in the above expression leads to

ψ​(x)=C​⟨ψh⟩s​ε​|ζ′​(x)|tan−1⁡(ε​|ζ′​(x)|).𝜓𝑥𝐶subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜓ℎ𝑠𝜀superscript𝜁′𝑥superscript1𝜀superscript𝜁′𝑥\psi(x)=C\langle\frac{\psi}{h}\rangle_{s}\frac{\varepsilon|\zeta^{\prime}(x)|}{\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon|\zeta^{\prime}(x)|)}. (85)

where tan−1superscripttan1\mathrm{tan}^{-1} is the arctangent function. Here we see that ψ′​(x)∼h′′​(x)similar-tosuperscript𝜓′𝑥superscriptℎ′′𝑥\psi^{\prime}(x)\sim h^{\prime\prime}(x) and thus the approximation made in (83) is consistent. Finally, multiplying both sides of Eq. (85) by 1/h=1/(ε​ζ)1ℎ1𝜀𝜁1/h=1/(\varepsilon\zeta) and integrating over [0,1]01[0,1] we find

C=⟨|h′​(x)|h​(x)​tan−1⁡(|h′​(x)|)⟩s−1,𝐶superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptℎ′𝑥ℎ𝑥superscript1superscriptℎ′𝑥𝑠1C=\left\langle\frac{|h^{\prime}(x)|}{h(x)\tan^{-1}(|h^{\prime}(x)|)}\right\rangle_{s}^{-1}, (86)

and thus Eq. (41) gives

DeD=1⟨h⟩s​⟨h′​(x)h​(x)​tan−1⁡(h′​(x))⟩s.subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptℎ′𝑥ℎ𝑥superscript1superscriptℎ′𝑥𝑠\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{\langle h\rangle_{s}\langle\frac{h^{\prime}(x)}{h(x)\tan^{-1}(h^{\prime}(x))}\rangle_{s}}. (87)

Within their systematic reduction to a one dimensional diffusion equation the authors of kal2006 show that the effective one dimensional diffusion constant that should be used in Eq. (15) is

D​(x)=D​tan−1⁡(h′​(x))h′​(x),𝐷𝑥𝐷superscript1superscriptℎ′𝑥superscriptℎ′𝑥D(x)=D\frac{\tan^{-1}\left(h^{\prime}(x)\right)}{h^{\prime}(x)}, (88)

and hence by using the Lifson-Jackson formula (15) we recover exactly the same formula (87) under the same approximation.

VI Generating Exact results

Here we re derive in a very direct manner a classical exact result due to Zwanzig zwa1982 for channels which can be appropriately parameterized in another coordinate system. Consider the transformation

z=G​(w)𝑧𝐺𝑤z=G(w) (89)

where z=x+i​y𝑧𝑥𝑖𝑦z=x+iy and w=u+i​v𝑤𝑢𝑖𝑣w=u+iv where G𝐺G is an analytic function. Importantly, the upper and lower channel boundaries are defined to be given by v=±V𝑣plus-or-minus𝑉v=\pm V where V𝑉V is constant. Of course the function G𝐺G must be chosen to be periodic in u𝑢u and should be single valued. Equation (78) is trivially written as

1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫x−i​h​(x)x+i​h​(x)𝑑ξ​ϕ​(ξ)=2​i​C,1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥differential-d𝜉italic-ϕ𝜉2𝑖𝐶\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int^{x+ih(x)}_{x-ih(x)}d\xi\ \phi(\xi)=2iC, (90)

where the integral is a contour integral over any finite contour joining the lower to upper limits indicated on the integral. Now in terms of the variables w𝑤w this becomes

1⟨ϕ⟩s​∫u−i​Vu+i​V𝑑w​d​Gd​w​ϕ​(w)=2​i​C.1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩italic-ϕ𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑢𝑖𝑉𝑢𝑖𝑉differential-d𝑤𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤italic-ϕ𝑤2𝑖𝐶\frac{1}{\langle\phi\rangle_{s}}\int^{u+iV}_{u-iV}dw\frac{dG}{dw}\phi(w)=2iC. (91)

The solution to this equation (up to a multiplicative constant) is now clearly given by

ϕ​(w)=[d​Gd​w]−1,italic-ϕ𝑤superscriptdelimited-[]𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤1\phi(w)=\left[\frac{dG}{dw}\right]^{-1}, (92)

which gives

C=V⟨[d​Gd​w]−1⟩s,𝐶𝑉subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptdelimited-[]𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤1𝑠C=\frac{V}{\left\langle\left[\frac{dG}{dw}\right]^{-1}\right\rangle_{s}}, (93)

and Eq. (41) now becomes

DeD=V⟨[d​Gd​w]−1⟩s​⟨h⟩s.subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷𝑉subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptdelimited-[]𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤1𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{V}{\left\langle\left[\frac{dG}{dw}\right]^{-1}\right\rangle_{s}\langle h\rangle_{s}}. (94)

This can be rewritten by noticing that ⟨h⟩s=Ω/2subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠Ω2\langle h\rangle_{s}=\Omega/2 is half the area of the unit cell and so we can write in the coordinate system given by w𝑤w

⟨h⟩s=12​∫01𝑑u​∫−VV𝑑v​|d​Gd​w|2.subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠12superscriptsubscript01differential-d𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑉differential-d𝑣superscript𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤2\langle h\rangle_{s}=\frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{1}du\int_{-V}^{V}dv\left|\frac{dG}{dw}\right|^{2}. (95)

For a symmetric channel we can make the line y=0𝑦0y=0 coincide with the line v=0𝑣0v=0, so G𝐺G is real for v=0𝑣0v=0,

⟨[d​Gd​w]−1⟩s=∫01𝑑x​[d​Gd​w|v=0]−1=∫01𝑑u​G′​(u)​[G′​(u)]−1=1,subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptdelimited-[]𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤1𝑠superscriptsubscript01differential-d𝑥superscriptdelimited-[]evaluated-at𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤𝑣01superscriptsubscript01differential-d𝑢superscript𝐺′𝑢superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐺′𝑢11\left\langle\left[\frac{dG}{dw}\right]^{-1}\right\rangle_{s}=\int_{0}^{1}dx\left[\left.\frac{dG}{dw}\right|_{v=0}\right]^{-1}=\int_{0}^{1}duG^{\prime}(u)[G^{\prime}(u)]^{-1}=1, (96)

where we have used the notation d​Gd​w|v=0=G′​(u)evaluated-at𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤𝑣0superscript𝐺′𝑢\frac{dG}{dw}|_{v=0}=G^{\prime}(u). Putting this altogether then gives

DeD=2​V∫01𝑑u​∫−VV𝑑v​|d​Gd​w|2.subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷2𝑉superscriptsubscript01differential-d𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑉differential-d𝑣superscript𝑑𝐺𝑑𝑤2\frac{D_{e}}{D}=2\frac{V}{\int_{0}^{1}du\int_{-V}^{V}dv|\frac{dG}{dw}|^{2}}. (97)

Up to differences in notation the above is identical to the result of Zwanzig zwa1982 .

VII The large ε𝜀\varepsilon limit

Here we can consider the case of very wide channels where we again write h​(x)=ε​ζ​(x)ℎ𝑥𝜀𝜁𝑥h(x)=\varepsilon\zeta(x) but we assume that ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\to\infty. Before analyzing this problem via the formalism developed above we propose a simple physical argument which gives a bound on the diffusion constant. Consider a symmetric channel whose height function about the center of the channel achieves its minimum value at some point xminsubscript𝑥minx_{\rm min} where it takes the value hminsubscriptℎminh_{\rm min}. Without loss of generality we choose xmin=−1/2≡1/2subscript𝑥min1212x_{\rm min}=-1/2\equiv 1/2. Now while the particle is in the region Ω′=[−1/2,1/2]×[−hmin,hmin]superscriptΩ′1212subscriptℎminsubscriptℎmin\Omega^{\prime}=[-1/2,1/2]\times[-h_{\rm min},h_{\rm min}] the particle diffuses without hindrance from the sides of the channel, so we can write

dd​t​⟨X2⟩=2​D,𝑑𝑑𝑡delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑋22𝐷\frac{d}{dt}\langle X^{2}\rangle=2D, (98)

however, outside of this region the diffusion is slowed down. If we denote by tΩ′subscript𝑡superscriptΩ′t_{\Omega^{\prime}} the total time spent in Ω′superscriptΩ′\Omega^{\prime} we can thus write

⟨X2⟩≥2​D​tΩ′,delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑋22𝐷subscript𝑡superscriptΩ′\langle X^{2}\rangle\geq 2Dt_{\Omega^{\prime}}, (99)

because time spent in the region where the walls can interfere with the diffusion will nonetheless contribute to diffusion - for example consider small excursions into this region which come back into Ω′superscriptΩ′\Omega^{\prime} having moved along the channel.

As we know the equilibrium distribution in the channel modulo the period is uniform, ergodicity then implies that

tΩ′t=|Ω′||Ω|=hmin⟨h⟩ssubscript𝑡superscriptΩ′𝑡superscriptΩ′Ωsubscriptℎminsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠\frac{t_{\Omega^{\prime}}}{t}=\frac{|\Omega^{\prime}|}{|\Omega|}=\frac{h_{\rm min}}{\langle h\rangle_{s}} (100)

which gives the bound

⟨X2⟩≥2​D​hmin⟨h⟩s​tdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑋22𝐷subscriptℎminsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠𝑡\langle X^{2}\rangle\geq 2D\frac{h_{\rm min}}{\langle h\rangle_{s}}t (101)

and thus we have the bound on the effective diffusion constant along the channel

DeD≥hmin⟨h⟩s=ζmin⟨ζ⟩s.subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷subscriptℎminsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠subscript𝜁minsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠\frac{D_{e}}{D}\geq\frac{h_{\rm min}}{\langle h\rangle_{s}}=\frac{\zeta_{\rm min}}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}. (102)

It is also clear that De≤Dsubscript𝐷𝑒𝐷D_{e}\leq D and thus we have the two sided bound

1≥DeD≥ζmin⟨ζ⟩s,1subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷subscript𝜁minsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠1\geq\frac{D_{e}}{D}\geq\frac{\zeta_{\rm min}}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}, (103)

and this simple result shows one that the system has a finite diffusion coefficient even in the limit ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\to\infty. In dea1993 diffusion on comb-like locally one dimensional structures was studied. The comb consists of a one dimensional backbone along which the diffusion is measured with teeth perpendicular to the backbone, excursions into the teeth slow down diffusion along the background. In this case the lower bound in Eq. (103) becomes exact as no diffusion can occur in the teeth due to their one dimensional character and given they are perpendicular to the backbone. Other problems of biased diffusion in tubes with dead-ends are studied in goo1960 ; dag2007 ; ber2011b .

To go beyond this analysis we consider a channel where the points x=±1/2𝑥plus-or-minus12x=\pm 1/2 correspond to the minimum of the height of the channel. The height at x=±1/2𝑥plus-or-minus12x=\pm 1/2 is, as above, denoted by hminsubscriptℎminh_{\rm min}. To start with we define a function w~​(z)~𝑤𝑧\tilde{w}(z) via

w​(z)=z+w~​(z),𝑤𝑧𝑧~𝑤𝑧w(z)=z+\tilde{w}(z), (104)

where w​(z)𝑤𝑧w(z) is the solution sought in Eq. (33). The boundary Eq. (38) contain now becomes

w~​(x+i​h​(x))−w~​(x−i​h​(x))=−i​2​C,~𝑤𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥~𝑤𝑥𝑖ℎ𝑥𝑖2𝐶\tilde{w}\left(x+ih(x)\right)-\tilde{w}\left(x-ih(x)\right)=-i2C, (105)

however, the function w~~𝑤\tilde{w} is no longer periodic and we find

w~​(x+1+i​y)−w~​(x+i​y)=−1.~𝑤𝑥1𝑖𝑦~𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦1\tilde{w}(x+1+iy)-\tilde{w}(x+iy)=-1. (106)

Now we make the transformation ξ=exp⁡[−i​π​(z−i​hmin)]𝜉𝑖𝜋𝑧𝑖subscriptℎmin\xi=\exp\left[-i\pi(z-ih_{\rm min})\right]. This conformal mapping is made explicit in the simple case where ΩΩ\Omega is the septate channel shown in Fig. 1 and where we denote by hmaxsubscriptℎmaxh_{\mathrm{max}} the maximal channel height. The domain shown in Fig. 1a also represents the region in which the original function w​(z)𝑤𝑧w(z) is analytic. In Fig. 1b we show the same region but include the branch cuts over which the function w~​(z)~𝑤𝑧\tilde{w}(z) jumps. In this case the domain ΩΩ\Omega is mapped into that shown on the Fig. 1c, where the radius of the outer half-circle Cγsubscript𝐶𝛾C_{\gamma} is given by γ=exp⁡[π​(hmax−hmin)]𝛾𝜋subscriptℎmaxsubscriptℎmin\gamma=\exp\left[{\pi}(h_{\rm max}-h_{\rm min})\right] and that of the inner circle Cλsubscript𝐶𝜆C_{\lambda} is λ=exp⁡[−π​(hmax+hmin)]𝜆𝜋subscriptℎmaxsubscriptℎmin\lambda=\exp\left[-\pi(h_{\rm max}+h_{\rm min})\right]. The crucial point is that in the limit ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\to\infty the radius γ𝛾\gamma becomes infinite while the radius λ𝜆\lambda goes to zero (we recall that hℎh is proportional to ε𝜀\varepsilon). For a general channel the points on the upper surface are mapped to a point at infinity while those on the lower surface are mapped to 00. We therefore argue that the obtained results will be valid for large ε𝜀\varepsilon for arbitrary channel shapes, since the details of the shape profile are sent to infinity after the mapping to the ξ𝜉\xi space.

The resulting Laplace problem on the new domain corresponds to a classic two dimensional electrostatic problem, one has two charged plates, where the potential is ϕ=1/2italic-ϕ12\phi=1/2 on an upper plate, between (0,0)00(0,0) and (0,1)01(0,1), and ϕ=−1/2italic-ϕ12\phi=-1/2 on the lower plate, between (0,0)00(0,0) and (0,−1)01(0,-1). The potential vanishes at infinity. The solution is given by w~​(ξ)=iπ​arcsinh​(1/ξ)~𝑤𝜉𝑖𝜋arcsinh1𝜉\tilde{w}(\xi)=\frac{i}{\pi}\rm{arcsinh}(1/\xi). The solution w​(z)𝑤𝑧w(z) found here can include an arbitrary, undetermined, imaginary constant, corresponding to the unimportant constant v0subscript𝑣0v_{0} in Eq. (36). Taking the logarithmic representation of arcsinharcsinh\rm{arcsinh}, we find

w​(x+i​y)=iπ​ln⁡[1+1+exp⁡(−2​π​i​x+2​π​(y−hmin))]+i​C~.𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑖𝜋112𝜋𝑖𝑥2𝜋𝑦subscriptℎmin𝑖~𝐶w(x+iy)=\frac{i}{\pi}\ln\left[1+\sqrt{1+\exp\left(-{2\pi}ix+{2\pi}(y-h_{\rm min})\right)}\right]+i\tilde{C}. (107)

where C~~𝐶\tilde{C} is a constant. We note that, for y≪hminmuch-less-than𝑦subscriptℎminy\ll h_{\rm min} and hmin≫1much-greater-thansubscriptℎmin1h_{\rm min}\gg 1, we have w​(x)=i​ln⁡(2)/π+i​C~𝑤𝑥𝑖2𝜋𝑖~𝐶w(x)=i\ln(2)/\pi+i\tilde{C}, and we recall that the choice v0=0subscript𝑣00v_{0}=0 means that the imaginary part vanishes on the central line y=0𝑦0y=0, this fixes the value of C~=−ln⁡(2)/π~𝐶2𝜋\tilde{C}=-\ln(2)/\pi. The above equation is valid for y>0𝑦0y>0. For y<0𝑦0y<0 the solution can be determined by symmetry to be w​(z¯)=w¯​(z)𝑤¯𝑧¯𝑤𝑧w(\overline{z})=\overline{w}(z).

Next we note that w​(x+i​y)−w​(x−i​y)𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦w(x+iy)-w(x-iy) in Eq.(38) is simply 2​i​Im​[w​(x+i​y)]2𝑖Imdelimited-[]𝑤𝑥𝑖𝑦2i\text{Im}[w(x+iy)], so that we can rewrite this equation and identify the constant C𝐶C, considering the limit h​(x)≫1much-greater-thanℎ𝑥1h(x)\gg 1,

C=hmin+ln⁡2π𝐶subscriptℎmin2𝜋\displaystyle C=h_{\rm min}+\frac{\ln 2}{\pi} (108)

and finally we use Eq. (41) to find

DeD=ζmin⟨ζ⟩s+1ε​ln⁡2π​⟨ζ⟩s.subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷subscript𝜁minsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠1𝜀2𝜋subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{\zeta_{\rm min}}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}+\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\frac{\ln 2}{\pi\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}. (109)

and we thus recover within our complex formalism the result of Ref.  man2017 . This result clearly agrees with the ergodic argument given earlier when ε→∞→𝜀\varepsilon\to\infty. We see that for finite ε𝜀\varepsilon the diffusion is faster for the reasons evoked above. However, this result is rather intriguing, firstly the fact that the correction scales as 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon is far from obvious. Another remarkable feature is that this correction depends only on the average height function through 1/⟨ζ⟩s1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠1/\langle\zeta\rangle_{s} and moreover the associated prefactor ln⁡(2)/π2𝜋\ln(2)/\pi is universal. These analytical results are valid for any channel shape in the limit of wide channels, as will be confirmed in a number of numerical tests in the following section.

VIII Numerical results

In this section we will show how the diffusion constant for periodic channels may be computed numerically. We use a standard finite element partial differential equation solver to (i) solve Laplace’s equation Eq. (25) with the integral constraint Eq. (26) and the boundary condition in Eq. (27) and (ii) carryout the subsequent evaluation of the effective diffusion constant via Eq. (24). The results obtained are used to test some of the analytical results derived here and elsewhere in the literature.

VIII.1 The exact result of Zwanzig

In zwa1982 Zwanzig considered a symmetric channel parameterized using the curvilinear coordinate system defined by

z=w+a​sin⁡(w),𝑧𝑤𝑎𝑤z=w+a\sin(w), (110)

which is equivalent to

x𝑥\displaystyle x =\displaystyle= u+a​cosh⁡(v)​sin⁡(u)𝑢𝑎𝑣𝑢\displaystyle u+a\cosh(v)\sin(u) (111)
y𝑦\displaystyle y =\displaystyle= v+a​sinh⁡(v)​cos⁡(u),𝑣𝑎𝑣𝑢\displaystyle v+a\sinh(v)\cos(u), (112)

where the boundaries of the channel are given by v=±V𝑣plus-or-minus𝑉v=\pm V. The height of the channel is single valued for α=a​cosh⁡(V)<1𝛼𝑎𝑉1\alpha=a\cosh(V)<1. An example of such a channel is shown in Fig. 2a.

In this case Zwanzig showed that

DeD=11+α2​tanh⁡(V)V,subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷11superscript𝛼2𝑉𝑉\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{\alpha^{2}\tanh(V)}{V}}, (113)

which can be easily verified using Eq. (97). The existence of this exact result serves as a useful verification of the general formulas derived here for the diffusion equation (Eqs. (24-27)) along with our numerical resolution of the associated partial differential equations. The effective diffusion constant is shown in Fig. 2b for a channel with periodicity 2​π2𝜋2\pi with V=0.5𝑉0.5V=0.5 for values of a𝑎a taken between 00 (the flat channel) through to the maximal value of a𝑎a for which the channel height is a single valued function - the agreement is seen to be perfect.

VIII.2 Linear channel

Here we consider dispersion in channels with piece wise linear profiles. Such channels are of interest as they are static/non-active realizations of the saw-tooth potentials often used to study ratchets and also because of the existence of the piece wise linear approximation scheme of Ref. kal2006 , re derived here as Eq. (87). For concreteness we consider two linear channel profiles. We consider the periodic symmetric saw-tooth height profile h​(x)=ε​ζ​(x)ℎ𝑥𝜀𝜁𝑥h(x)=\varepsilon\zeta(x) where ζ​(x)=a+|x|𝜁𝑥𝑎𝑥\zeta(x)=a+|x| for x∈[−1/2,1/2]𝑥1212x\in[-1/2,1/2] and shown in Fig. 3a, already studied by ber2007 ; dag2010 ; ber2015 ; ver2016 , as well as the ratchet-like height profile ζ​(x)=a+x𝜁𝑥𝑎𝑥\zeta(x)=a+x on [0,1]01[0,1] shown in Fig. 3b. In the first case the channel height is continuous and Eq. (87) thus predicts that for the saw-tooth channel we have

DeD=2​tan−1⁡(ε)ε​(4​a+1)​ln⁡(1+12​a)subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷2superscript1𝜀𝜀4𝑎1112𝑎\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{2\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon)}{\varepsilon(4a+1)\ln(1+\frac{1}{2a})} (114)

However, for the ratchet channel the discontinuity in ζ𝜁\zeta means that Eq. (87) has some ambiguity. To solve the ambiguity we replace the discontinuity at x=0, 1𝑥01x=0,\ 1 by defining a finite size x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} and taking ζ𝜁\zeta to be a straight line between (x0,a+x0)subscript𝑥0𝑎subscript𝑥0(x_{0},a+x_{0}) and (1,a)1𝑎(1,a) (at the end of the calculation we take the limit x0→1→subscript𝑥01x_{0}\to 1). This entails writing

ζ​(x)={a+xx∈[0,x0]a+α​(1−x)x∈[x0,1],𝜁𝑥cases𝑎𝑥𝑥0subscript𝑥0𝑎𝛼1𝑥𝑥subscript𝑥01\zeta(x)=\begin{cases}a+x~{}~{}~{}&x\in[0,x_{0}]\\ a+\alpha(1-x)~{}~{}~{}&x\in[x_{0},1]\end{cases}, (115)

where α=x01−x0𝛼subscript𝑥01subscript𝑥0\alpha=\frac{x_{0}}{1-x_{0}} by continuity at x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}. Taking the limit x0→1→subscript𝑥01x_{0}\to 1 then recovers the ratchet channel. For a given value of x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} we find

⟨ε​ζ′​(x)ε​ζ​(x)​tan−1⁡(ε​ζ′​(x))⟩s=εtan−1⁡(ε)​∫0x0d​xa+x+α​εtan−1⁡(ε​α)​∫x01d​xα​(1−x)+a=εtan−1⁡(ε)​ln⁡(1+x0a)+εtan−1⁡(ε​α)​ln⁡(1+x0a),subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜀superscript𝜁′𝑥𝜀𝜁𝑥superscript1𝜀superscript𝜁′𝑥𝑠𝜀superscript1𝜀superscriptsubscript0subscript𝑥0𝑑𝑥𝑎𝑥𝛼𝜀superscript1𝜀𝛼superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥01𝑑𝑥𝛼1𝑥𝑎𝜀superscript1𝜀1subscript𝑥0𝑎𝜀superscript1𝜀𝛼1subscript𝑥0𝑎\begin{split}\left\langle\frac{\varepsilon\zeta^{\prime}(x)}{\varepsilon\zeta(x)\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon\zeta^{\prime}(x))}\right\rangle_{s}&=\frac{\varepsilon}{\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon)}\int_{0}^{x_{0}}\frac{dx}{a+x}+\frac{\alpha\varepsilon}{\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon\alpha)}\int_{x_{0}}^{1}\frac{dx}{\alpha(1-x)+a}\\ &=\frac{\varepsilon}{\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon)}\ln\left(1+\frac{x_{0}}{a}\right)+\frac{\varepsilon}{\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon\alpha)}\ln\left(1+\frac{x_{0}}{a}\right),\end{split} (116)

and taking the limit x0→1→subscript𝑥01x_{0}\to 1 we find,

⟨ε​ζ′​(x)ε​ζ​(x)​tan−1⁡(ε​ζ′​(x))⟩s=ε​(2π+1tan−1⁡(ε))​ln⁡(1+1a),subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜀superscript𝜁′𝑥𝜀𝜁𝑥superscript1𝜀superscript𝜁′𝑥𝑠𝜀2𝜋1superscript1𝜀11𝑎\left\langle\frac{\varepsilon\zeta^{\prime}(x)}{\varepsilon\zeta(x)\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon\zeta^{\prime}(x))}\right\rangle_{s}=\varepsilon\left(\frac{2}{\pi}+\frac{1}{\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon)}\right)\ln\left(1+\frac{1}{a}\right), (117)

which yields

DeD=1ε​(a+12)​(2π+1tan−1⁡(ε))​ln⁡(1+1a).subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷1𝜀𝑎122𝜋1superscript1𝜀11𝑎\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon\left(a+\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(\frac{2}{\pi}+\frac{1}{\tan^{-1}(\varepsilon)}\right)\ln\left(1+\frac{1}{a}\right)}. (118)

The comparison of the piece wise linear approximation with the exact results is shown in Fig. 3c we see that the approximation clearly fails for the ratchet channel, since the deviations from the basic FJ approximation are not well captured by the piece wise linear approximation. In turn, the piece wise linear approximation is reasonable for the saw-tooth profile for values of ε𝜀\varepsilon of order 111. This may linked to the fact that this approximation is exact at order ε2superscript𝜀2\varepsilon^{2}. In both cases, the piece wise linear approximation underestimates the effective diffusion constant for large ε𝜀\varepsilon. Indeed, in general the piece wise approximation predicts that the effective diffusion constant behaves as De∼1/εsimilar-tosubscript𝐷𝑒1𝜀D_{e}\sim 1/\varepsilon for large ε𝜀\varepsilon. This is at variance with the exact numerical calculation and the large ε𝜀\varepsilon analysis of section VII where the effective diffusion constant saturates to a non-zero asymptotic limit (De→a/(a+1/4)→subscript𝐷𝑒𝑎𝑎14D_{e}\to a/(a+1/4) for the saw-tooth and De→a/(a+1/2)→subscript𝐷𝑒𝑎𝑎12D_{e}\to a/(a+1/2) for the ratchet). For the parameters a=1/4𝑎14a=1/4 for the saw tooth case and a=1/2𝑎12a=1/2 for the ratchet, the predicted large ε𝜀\varepsilon result is De→1/2→subscript𝐷𝑒12D_{e}\to 1/2 for both cases, in perfect agreement with the numerical results shown in Fig. 3.

VIII.3 Smooth channel

In this section we consider the case of a smoothly varying channel where all terms appearing in the perturbation series solution for the effective diffusion constant Desubscript𝐷𝑒D_{e}, derived in section IV.2 are finite. In particularly we will show how a formula, which fits the numerical evaluation for the diffusion constant, can be derived for all values of ε𝜀\varepsilon using a Padé type re summation of the small ε𝜀\varepsilon perturbation expansion along with the first two terms (the 𝒪​(1)𝒪1{\cal O}(1) and 𝒪​(1/ε)𝒪1𝜀{\cal O}(1/\varepsilon) ones) in the large ε𝜀\varepsilon expansion derived in section VII. In addition we will demonstrate numerically certain of the key results derived in this paper in the large and small ε𝜀\varepsilon regimes.

For the purposes of this section we consider the channel defined by

ζ​(x)=1.5+0.266​[cos⁡(2​π​x)+sin⁡(6​π​x)].𝜁𝑥1.50.266delimited-[]2𝜋𝑥6𝜋𝑥\zeta(x)=1.5+0.266\left[\cos(2\pi x)+\sin(6\pi x)\right]. (119)

In order to compare numerical results for different values of ε𝜀\varepsilon we define Y=y/ε𝑌𝑦𝜀Y=y/\varepsilon. Shown in Figs. 4a-c is the numerically evaluated function f​(x,Y)𝑓𝑥𝑌f(x,Y) for values of ε𝜀\varepsilon given respectively by ε=0.01, 0.5𝜀0.010.5\varepsilon=0.01,\ 0.5 and 100100100. First, at small values of ε𝜀\varepsilon we see that the solution f​(x,Y)𝑓𝑥𝑌f(x,Y) shown in Fig. 4a is independent of Y𝑌Y, this is the underlying hypothesis behind the FJ approximation and we see that for this narrow channel the approximation is works well. On increasing ε𝜀\varepsilon to 0.50.50.5, in Fig. 4b, we see that the solution develops a dependence on Y𝑌Y. Finally for large ε𝜀\varepsilon, Fig. 4c, we see that the analysis of section VII is confirmed. Firstly we see that the solution vanishes within the part of the channel |Y|<ζm𝑌subscript𝜁𝑚|Y|<\zeta_{m} to high numerical accuracy, while the solution becomes, as for the small ε𝜀\varepsilon case, independent of Y𝑌Y in the region |Y|>ζm𝑌subscript𝜁𝑚|Y|>\zeta_{m} and takes the approximate form f​(x,y)≈x𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑥f(x,y)\approx x.

We now consider the accuracy of the perturbation theory developed in this paper based on the small ε𝜀\varepsilon expansion, which for the smooth channel considered here is always well defined. Shown in Fig. 5a is the result of the perturbation theory starting at order 𝒪​(ε2)𝒪superscript𝜀2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}), through to that at 𝒪​(ε6)𝒪superscript𝜀6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}) along with the exact numerical evaluation of the diffusion constant. The results clearly improve with increasing the order of the perturbation expansion – however, they all depart strongly from the exact result when ε𝜀\varepsilon is 𝒪​(1)𝒪1{\cal O}(1). Furthermore the perturbation expansion appears to give lower bounds when taken at 𝒪​(ε2)𝒪superscript𝜀2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}) and 𝒪​(ε6)𝒪superscript𝜀6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}) and upper bounds when taken at 𝒪​(ε4)𝒪superscript𝜀4{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{4}) (without any re summation). This alternating structure in the perturbation expansion is also seen for diffusion in random Gaussian potentials dea94 ; dea95 . The problem with this alternating structure of the perturbation theory is that the diffusion constant will either become negative or greater than D𝐷D (which is clearly not possible on physical grounds) depending on the order of perturbation theory employed. In addition, we have seen that Desubscript𝐷𝑒D_{e} saturates at large values of ε𝜀\varepsilon which is incompatible with a pure polynomial expansion in ε𝜀\varepsilon. Based on the 𝒪​(ε2)𝒪superscript𝜀2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}) result of perturbation theory a number of authors have proposed the following alternative forms, which of course agree at 𝒪​(ε2)𝒪superscript𝜀2{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{2}) with the basic perturbation theory result. In our notation these alternative expressions are

DeD=1⟨ζ⟩s​⟨ζ−1⟩s​11+ε2​⟨ζ′⁣2/ζ⟩s3​⟨ζ−1⟩s,subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁1𝑠11superscript𝜀2subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁′2𝜁𝑠3subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁1𝑠\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}}\frac{1}{1+\varepsilon^{2}\frac{\langle\zeta^{\prime 2}/\zeta\rangle_{s}}{3\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}}}, (120)

proposed in zwa1991 . Another alternative is given by

DeD=1⟨ζ⟩s​⟨(1+ε2​ζ′⁣2)13ζ⟩s−1,subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript1superscript𝜀2superscript𝜁′213𝜁𝑠1\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}\langle\frac{(1+\varepsilon^{2}\zeta^{\prime 2})^{\frac{1}{3}}}{\zeta}\rangle_{s}^{-1}, (121)

which was given in reg2001 . A third alternative is given by Eq. (87), originally proposed in kal2006 . The comparison of these approximations with the exact numerical evaluation for the diffusion constant for the case in hand is shown in Fig. 5b. The advantage of these formulations is that the effective diffusion constant is now bounded within the region [0,D]0𝐷[0,D]. However, in the limit of large ε𝜀\varepsilon all these proposed forms predict that the diffusion constant becomes zero and all are significantly different from the exact result for ε𝜀\varepsilon of order 1. The last question we will therefore address here is whether there is a way to tie up the small and large ε𝜀\varepsilon results derived here to obtain a formula describing the effective diffusion constant for all values of ε𝜀\varepsilon? Below we will pursue a Padé like approximant scheme which exploits both regimes of the perturbation theory studied in this paper.

We begin by writing the small ε𝜀\varepsilon expansion for the effective diffusivity given by Eq. (67)

DeD=1⟨ζ⟩s​⟨ζ−1⟩s​[1−⟨ζ′⁣2/ζ⟩s3​⟨ζ−1⟩s​ε2+(⟨ζ′⁣2/ζ⟩s29​⟨ζ−1⟩s2+4​⟨ζ′⁣4/ζ⟩s+⟨ζ′′⁣2​ζ⟩s45​⟨ζ−1⟩s)​ε4+…]=DFJ​[1+λ2​ε2+λ4​ε4+…],subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁1𝑠delimited-[]1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁′2𝜁𝑠3subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁1𝑠superscript𝜀2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁′2𝜁𝑠29superscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁1𝑠24subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁′4𝜁𝑠subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁′′2𝜁𝑠45subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩superscript𝜁1𝑠superscript𝜀4…subscript𝐷FJdelimited-[]1subscript𝜆2superscript𝜀2subscript𝜆4superscript𝜀4…\begin{split}\frac{D_{e}}{D}&=\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}}\left[1-\frac{\langle\zeta^{\prime 2}/\zeta\rangle_{s}}{3\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}}\varepsilon^{2}+\left(\frac{\langle\zeta^{\prime 2}/\zeta\rangle_{s}^{2}}{9\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}^{2}}+\frac{4\langle\zeta^{\prime 4}/\zeta\rangle_{s}+\langle\zeta^{\prime\prime 2}\zeta\rangle_{s}}{45\langle\zeta^{-1}\rangle_{s}}\right)\varepsilon^{4}+...\right]\\ &=D_{\rm FJ}\left[1+\lambda_{2}\varepsilon^{2}+\lambda_{4}\varepsilon^{4}+...\right],\end{split} (122)

where λi=CiC0subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐶0\lambda_{i}=\frac{C_{i}}{C_{0}}. In principle one can gain in precision by also using the 𝒪​(ε6)𝒪superscript𝜀6{\cal O}(\varepsilon^{6}) correction, though the resulting algebraic complication does not really justify the gain in accuracy. Using the large ε𝜀\varepsilon expansion developed in section VII we also write

DeD=1⟨ζ⟩s​[ζmin+ln⁡2π​ε+…]=D∞​[1+αε+…].subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷1subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝜁𝑠delimited-[]subscript𝜁min2𝜋𝜀…subscript𝐷delimited-[]1𝛼𝜀…\frac{D_{e}}{D}=\frac{1}{\langle\zeta\rangle_{s}}\left[\zeta_{\rm min}+\frac{\ln 2}{\pi\varepsilon}+...\right]=D_{\infty}\left[1+\frac{\alpha}{\varepsilon}+...\right]. (123)

A Padé type re summation is constructed by writing

DeD=DFJ​1+a1​ε+a2​ε2+a3​ε31+b1​ε+b2​ε2+b3​ε3,subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷subscript𝐷FJ1subscript𝑎1𝜀subscript𝑎2superscript𝜀2subscript𝑎3superscript𝜀31subscript𝑏1𝜀subscript𝑏2superscript𝜀2subscript𝑏3superscript𝜀3\frac{D_{e}}{D}=D_{\rm FJ}\frac{1+a_{1}\varepsilon+a_{2}\varepsilon^{2}+a_{3}\varepsilon^{3}}{1+b_{1}\varepsilon+b_{2}\varepsilon^{2}+b_{3}\varepsilon^{3}}, (124)

where the aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} are obtained from the two expansions, for small and large ε𝜀\varepsilon. The coefficients are found to be given by

a1=b1=[λ22+λ4​(K−1)]​(K−1)λ22​K​αa2=λ2−λ4λ2b2=−λ4λ2a3=K​b3=λ22+λ4​(K−1)λ2​αK=D∞DFJ.subscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜆22subscript𝜆4𝐾1𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜆22𝐾𝛼subscript𝑎2subscript𝜆2subscript𝜆4subscript𝜆2subscript𝑏2subscript𝜆4subscript𝜆2subscript𝑎3𝐾subscript𝑏3superscriptsubscript𝜆22subscript𝜆4𝐾1subscript𝜆2𝛼𝐾subscript𝐷subscript𝐷FJ\begin{split}a_{1}&=b_{1}=\frac{[\lambda_{2}^{2}+\lambda_{4}(K-1)](K-1)}{\lambda_{2}^{2}K\alpha}\\ a_{2}&=\lambda_{2}-\frac{\lambda_{4}}{\lambda_{2}}\\ b_{2}&=-\frac{\lambda_{4}}{\lambda_{2}}\\ a_{3}&=Kb_{3}=\frac{\lambda_{2}^{2}+\lambda_{4}(K-1)}{\lambda_{2}\alpha}\\ K&=\frac{D_{\infty}}{D_{\rm FJ}}.\end{split} (125)

The results of this approximation for the class of channels described by Eq. (119) is shown in Fig. 5b. We see that the resulting approximation is in very good agreement with the exact numerical results and that, as is to be expected, the maximum errors arise in the crossover region where ε𝜀\varepsilon is of order 111.

IX Conclusion

In this paper we have examined the effective dispersion of Brownian particles in a channel geometry. Rather than attempting to write an effective one-dimensional diffusion equation to describe the system as in many past studies, we have exploited a direct formula for the effective diffusion constant which is obtained from the system of time independent equations Eqs. (24-27) which were derived here for completeness but are in agreement with a general theory of dispersion coefficients developed in gue2015a and gue2015b and also with the macro transport theory of Brenner bre1993 when applied to the channel problem dorfman2014assessing . Using a formulation in terms of analytic functions [Eqs. (24,25,26,27)], we were able to develop a compact formulation of the perturbation theory in channel width scale ε𝜀\varepsilon. Notably we were able to show that the homogenization scheme proposed by Kalinay and Percus kal2006 gives the correct diffusion constant at order ε6superscript𝜀6\varepsilon^{6}. The exact results of Zwanzig for parameterized channels and the piece wise linear approximation of kal2006 can be deduced from the formalism developed here in a very compact manner. Most studies on diffusion in channels are focused on narrow channels. The formalism developed here was also exploited to study wide channels, yielding a physically intuitive result in the limit or very large channels but also giving the first non-trivial correction which takes a remarkably universal form. Finally we were able to show how the small and large ε𝜀\varepsilon expansions for the effective diffusion constant can be combined in a Padé type approximant which accurately describe continuous channels for all values of ε𝜀\varepsilon.

There are a number of potential extensions of this work based on the static approach proposed in gue2015a ; gue2015b which can be extended to systems having a current in their equilibrium states. This means that the approach could be applied to dispersion in channels with driving forces both along the channel and normal to the channel gho2010 ; bur2008 ; burada2009diffusion (arising from gravity for example). Furthermore the approach of gue2015a ; gue2015b can also be adapted to extract the finite time behavior of transport coefficients and could be applied to the problem of diffusion in channels.

If we use the symmetries u​(x,−y)=u​(x,y)𝑢𝑥𝑦𝑢𝑥𝑦u(x,-y)=u(x,y) and v​(x,−y)=−v​(x,y)𝑣𝑥𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦v(x,-y)=-v(x,y), and the periodicity in x𝑥x of all functions, the expression becomes

∫𝒞𝑑z​w​(z)=2​i​∫0L𝑑x​[h′​(x)​u​(x,h​(x))+v​(x,h​(x))]=0.subscript𝒞differential-d𝑧𝑤𝑧2𝑖superscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥delimited-[]superscriptℎ′𝑥𝑢𝑥ℎ𝑥𝑣𝑥ℎ𝑥0\displaystyle\int_{\mathcal{C}}dzw(z)=2i\int_{0}^{L}dx[h^{\prime}(x)u(x,h(x))+v(x,h(x))]=0. (128)

From Eq. (40), we obtain

DeD=1+2Ω​∫0L𝑑x​h′​(x)​u​(x,h​(x))=1−2Ω​∫0L𝑑x​v​(x,h​(x)),subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷12Ωsuperscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥superscriptℎ′𝑥𝑢𝑥ℎ𝑥12Ωsuperscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥𝑣𝑥ℎ𝑥\displaystyle\frac{D_{e}}{D}=1+\frac{2}{\Omega}\int_{0}^{L}dxh^{\prime}(x)u(x,h(x))=1-\frac{2}{\Omega}\int_{0}^{L}dxv(x,h(x)), (129)

and the boundary condition (38) yields

DeD=1−2Ω​∫0L𝑑x​[h​(x)−C]=C⟨h⟩s.subscript𝐷𝑒𝐷12Ωsuperscriptsubscript0𝐿differential-d𝑥delimited-[]ℎ𝑥𝐶𝐶subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩ℎ𝑠\displaystyle\frac{D_{e}}{D}=1-\frac{2}{\Omega}\int_{0}^{L}dx[h(x)-C]=\frac{C}{\langle h\rangle_{s}}. (130)
